SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

Abstract of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The extra sheets at the end there is not sufficient space to answer all the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, but may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questionnaires, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Have?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Enclosure of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Not much. Some thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or church group)?

We came alone and my brother alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came on the Allan Line Caribou.

My wife and two children came on the same train.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other exciting events.)

Well what a long story, on the Caribou we had a cattle boat there, about 30 friends, Santa Claus South of Prince Rupert, took native, full grown.

No horses, no sleighs, no blankets, no food, no sugar, no coffee, no tea, no flour, no meat, no margarine, no Grand Tuck for supper, William Boon, the officer, he gave us a lot of encouragement.

The Sr. Mr. Family and the Governor were at the head of the trip.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Mr. Macdonald Hotel, my wife, my life, and myself.

Coffee, tea, and all the necessities.

16. What was your first job in Saskatchewan?

I worked on the farm for Mr. Smith.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Everything was very hard, but they were lots of work. We got to work right away.

Lots of weeks without pay, but we could be called, called, called, more land, for potatoes, wood, fruit, cheese, more land, for potatoes, etc.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Not much. People may have thought to get a cash job in Winnipeg.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

I came alone with my brother about a month before the bus came.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

My wife and two children came on the bus and we traveled on a farm at Marmora, Ont.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other events, etc.)

Well that's a long story, but the main thing was that we traveled on a cattle boat there, which was about 30 feet long. We started from Toronto, Ontario, and traveled all the way to Marmora, Ont.

15. Where did you first settle when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Mr. Madison Valley, near Marmora, Ont.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We lived in Marmora, Ont., then moved to Saskatoon, Sask., and finally settled in Regina, Sask.

17. How long have you been living in Saskatchewan?

Since 1904.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Every thing in England was very cheap, but everything here was very expensive. We worked hard to earn enough money to buy land, called "homesteads," in the Canadian Prairies, called "prairie" land, for settlers.

Coreyville in the early 1900s had two churches,

One called "The Fourth Church," known as the First Church in

the community before the founding of Vanderbilt Church.

In 1928, they merged with the "Old Covenant Church"

and became known as the "Fourth Church."

In 1943, they moved to the previous site and in 1948, they

merged with the "Old Covenant Church" and became known as

the "First Church" again.

The new church was destroyed by fire in 1943 and the old

church was sold to the town of Coreyville in 1948.

There used to be a school in Coreyville which burned to

the ground in 1948.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live, and occupations.

We had 4 Quads (all married now) in Bays. 3 are in business in Calgary. One is in the farm with me. We work 2 sections of land, surrounded by snow. Each year we grow 18 acres of wheat and 180 acres of hay.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The change taking place are that most of the people are moving to the cities. This is not a new thing. In every town 40 years ago, there was a mixture of farmers until in the village, people went out to work. The land was divided into 1/5 to 2/3 acres in the village. Most of these had from 2 to 4 quads of cattle & sheep & hogs and everybody used the plough.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

The changes taking place are that:
- Most of the people are moving out to the villages to live. This is not a new thing, but has been going on for years.
- The farmers until recently did not want the land in the village. Now there is a lot of cattle raised on the land.
- Most of them tried to get a piece of land.
